Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Don't care what others say, this still beats all the live action Disney movies by a mile, that includes Beauty and the Beast and Aladdin. This is the only one that improves on the original cartoon movie. The BatB and Aladdin had terrible singing (auto-tuned Belle, anyone?) and low-energy musical scenes (everything in Aladdin) and pointless changes to the story (Jasmine's whole character, filler CGI chase scene with mutant Iago) and needless addition of modern politics (Belle's feminism). I love that this Cinderella celebrates traditional femininity, kindness and forgiveness. Every other Disney movie is now about STRONK INDEPENDENT WAMEN WHO DON'T NEED NO MAN, as if leaning on other people = dependent and is something to be ashamed of, and how revenge and evil getting paid with evil is something to strive for.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: I couldn't believe how similar this story is to mine. I had the same characters in my life as Cinderella did. An abusive step mother, The jealous aunt and her two competitive daughters, the birds I loved feeding, an angel who came in to my life to make me realize God's love for me and above all a beautiful set of parents who always taught me good values like kindness n love. and yes the house story too. I even noticed some of the dialogues in the movie tht I had with my dad. I don't expect a prince charming to come becoz i know God is my only lover. Its amazing how somebody's fantasy could be actually happening to someone many years later. Did God steal the script?

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Casting, acting, effects, music, costumes, setting, all were spot on.  I don't think I have ever liked a live adaptation of a Disney movie ever (with the exception of the French version of Beauty and the Beast) and this one was just so above and beyond any other.  Not only do I like this one, I love it.  The biggest crime is the costume department not winning the Oscar -__-

Who's here in 2019?

Rewatching this film, I think it beats Beauty and the Beast storywise. I was touched by the ending of BATB, cried a little. But this one, f*ck, it's more touching. Cried when fairy godmother transformed her, cried when she arrived at the palace, and cried in the end.

BATB beats Cinderella in music, though. But Sonna Rele's Strong is a really great song.

Looking forward to more Disney remakes.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
What being a princess has always meant to me.

1. Being independent.

2. Doing what's right even if all disagree.

3. Achieving the best in all that I do.

4. Being a leader.

5. Understanding that while I may be bigger, I am not better than any of the little bugs that crawl outside.

6. Finding new ways for myself to grow.

7. Learning the valuable lesson of hard work.

8. Educating myself in simple ways, it means no college.

9. Being humble enough to understand that I am not better than others.

10. Seeing the beauty in nature and understanding that life is an adventure, verses a destination. 

11. Finding my own way out of any destructive path I may find myself on.

Being a princess has never been about living in a castle or having the finest stuff in life. It is not about glamour for me or the superficial nature of things.

It is about who I am on the inside where no one else can see.

So the stepmother and Grand Duke were banished out of the kingdom.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: I found this movie completely contradicts with the ideas it's trying to sale the audience on. It trying to promote the idea of not to marry for advantage or money, instead we should marry for love. I found this to be hilarious because Ella marry a prince who's rich, tall and handsome. And ironically enough, Cinderella was a hot bombshell. I think if Disney really want to brain wash kids or whoever else still buys into this kind of crap nowadays that they should marry for love, then at least create a story that's more realistic for god sake. Like instead of letting Cinderella marry Prince Charming, they should let her marry a fatass butcher or servant. Moreover, instead of letting Prince Charming marry a hot bombshell, they should let him marry an ugly 200 pound girl. This way the movie would have been at least some what  meaningful, otherwise this movie just made me felt like I was watching a PG rated version of 50 shades of grey.

Many people kept on asking,  "how come Ella's shoes stayed the same while the others turned back to what it was before?" This is what I think = 

Explanation 1 = 
The other stuff was changed into something else, like lizard to footman, pumpkin to carriage. Now, Ella's shoes wasn't changed. She took her OLD shoes off her feet in the movie and then the fairy godmother made NEW shoes which is the glass one. So the other stuff turned back to what it was before and the shoes she wore to the party was already at its original form. It is not changed. It is already made like that. 

Explanation 2 = Everything is possible in a movie.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Saw this today and was actually blubbing like a bitch. And I never cry dammit! I think the strong actors really made you actually care when I was expecting it to be very shallow and too cartoonish to really take seriously. I know Cate gets all the big camp moments with the villain but I actually think its Lily James who carries the movie overall. She strikes the perfect balance between nice and charming but also feisty and strong; this bitch really knows who she is and will not let anybody spoil her day or wipe that optimistic smile off her face. She will not cry over being treated like shit by her step family or ever be a doormat to any man. Nor will she wait for some white knight to come get her; she was determined to go to that fucking ball and get that dick. Way ahead of her time. I believed in the chemistry between the two lovers. I also thought the King & princes relationship was touching especially the deathbed scene where the prince was curled up on the bed like a little boy. It had some very human moments. Again, it goes back to the actors playing it for real; Derek jacobi has such a strong presence as the king & both he and Cate gave the film strong theatrical credibility. But its Lilys film. Plus I love that they stayed faithful to the Disney classic. Fuck modern twists we have enough modern reality films.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: I read something very interesting on tumblr the other day, which has made me much more excited to see this movie. A lady was commenting on how most people see Cinderella as such a passive, non feminist story, because the girl hardly has any power and doesn't stand up to her stepfamily. But, this lady said, the story is actually very empowering in that Ella never once is cruel or vindictive or selfish, despite the horrible abuse she faces in her own home. The empowerment comes from Ella being able to stay good and pure of heart despite her hardships, and if u think she should have stood up against her abusers, you've obviously never heard a victim or survivor talk about how hard it is to defend yourself against it. It can be dangerous, even lethal, to try and leave your abusers home, and in that time period? Forget about it. So no, she doesn't fight, but yes, she is a good role model in that she endures and hopes and stays kind and generous despite others being so unkind to her. She is breaking the cycle of abuse--and that is a very powerful, incredible thing to happen in a story like this. As Ellas mum says, where there is kindness, there is goodness. And where there us goodness, there is magic.

The story of â€œCinderellaâ€ follows the fortunes of young Ella whose merchant father remarries following the tragic death of her mother. Keen to support her loving father, Ella welcomes her new stepmother Lady Tremaine and her daughters Anastasia and Drizella into the family home. But when Ellaâ€™s father suddenly and unexpectedly passes away, she finds herself at the mercy of a jealous and cruel new family. Finally relegated to nothing more than a servant girl covered in ashes, and spitefully renamed Cinderella since she used to work in the cinders, Ella could easily begin to lose hope. Yet, despite the cruelty inflicted upon her, Ella is determined to honor her motherâ€™s dying words and to â€œhave courage and be kind.â€ She will not give in to despair nor despise those who abuse her. Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Why must racist come out of the closet in YouTube comments?
I think it's a good idea to check history before speaking and forever being branded as a racist in public. People of African heritage were a common part of life in Europe for centuries. Before society began to put "white" "black" labels on people, race was not an issue. There were black nobleman during the 12th and 13th century in Europe. They were respected and seen as anyone else. They were guests of kings and queens due to their nobleman status. They weren't different. Their dark skin was just seen as another human feature.
Also, skeletal remains of a high society black male were found in the rumble of the Mount Vesuvius eruption which destroyed Pompeii, Greece in 79 AD. There are many many examples of people of Hispanic, African, and Asian heritage in European society and vice versa (Europeans in other culture's society). It's ridiculous how we are today. There's not white, black, mexican (which, if they weren't born in Mexico or have heritage from Mexico, can you please stop calling a person Mexican), or Chinese (same applies here). We are all an amazing mix of culture and heritage. Love yourself and love others as Jesus loves you. Respect all people and appreciate what all cultures have contributed to our way of life, from combing your hair (the comb started in Persia, which is Iranian) to the gas mask in WWI that has saved thousands of lives (which was invented by a black man in 1916). Every one of us matter.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
This movie was actually surprisingly good, I went in expecting something mediocre like Maleficent but instead I got exactly what I wanted. A live-action remake of the animated feature.

There were no big changes to the story like with Maleficent, only some extra padding to give each character a more fleshed out background, which lets be real here - the Prince was in dire need of.

Definitely the best of Disney's live-action adaptations as of yet and certainly proves that one doesn't need to go the "Darker and Edgier" route when it comes to remakes.

tl;dr - Multitudes of levels better than Maleficent, go see Cinderella if you want to leave the theater with a warm and fuzzy feeling in your belly instead of the hollow empty one you got from the former.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
It scares me just how popular the whole "colored people don't belong in this film because it's a European story!" opinion is.
A) in case the astoundingly time-period accurate costumes, hair, and architecture have confused you, this film doesn't take place in medieval France. It very very super duper clearly takes place in a fictitious fantasy universe that has fairy godmothers and glass dancing shoes. If they pulled a black casting choice in something like Ever After (a legitimate period piece) I would be distracted by it there, but not here.
B) The Cinderella story originated in China. If it's so "offensive" to so many whites that a colored Cinderella be portrayed in a European story, why is nobody up in arms about the Europeans who put a white girl in an Asian story?
C) Its a fucking children's movie.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: I saw this movie today, and while I wasn't expecting much before, I have to say now that it was AMAZING!!!  It was a beautiful film in every way.  The settings, the clothes and all the other little details were absolutely picturesque.  The acting was brilliant - I even teared up at some parts.  And the lesson of the entire story wasn't overdone to the point of being cheesy, but emphasized enough that I left the theater feeling so good about the world and wanting to "have courage and be kind."  And sure, the argument could be made that the movie is still a silly fairy tale teaching young girls that women need men or it's good to be a pushover or whatever else people are coming up with these days, but I really don't think every movie needs to feature some rebellious, "badass," "strong and independent" girl who absolutely refuses to be married or believe in anything beyond the confines of her own eyes.  There is nothing wrong with encouraging gentleness, unconditional kindness and faith in true love and magic.  In fact, in our ever-changing and robotic society, we could use a little magic every now and then.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
SPOILERS AHEAD:
So this movie, I felt did an okay job, but I still enjoyed the original cartoon version. I like the fact that they showed what happened to the mother, which is something that they didn't show in the original. The message was better stated here and the graphics were pretty great. Also, it had a nice twist with the stepmother breaking her glass slipper. But some of the main points weren't well presented in this film. The death of the father was sudden and it was thought that he was killed by the stepmother in the original, unlike the new one where he had an accident. Cinderella was a servant basically for eight years in the original, which makes her kindness more extraordinary as she had the patience with dealing her step family, even when she had to do so many chores without help and even several times if a minor mistake was made. This one, however, she was the only servant for less than a year, half of which she had help from the other servants. So she didn't really feel the abuse for a long period of time. The animals in this one were alive for an unusual amount of time because the average lifespan of a mouse is only 2 years, and these mice have been with Cinderella since she was 8 (so about 8 years). Also, Cinderella is her name, not a nick name. For her to take the name given to her by her stepsisters instead by her parents is kind of an insult. Sure you can say that it serves as a constant reminder of her abuse, but again, that wasn't for long period of time. Had she been enslaved at age 8, like the original one, I will accept it, but less than a year isn't long enough. Also, the fairy god mother was more like a hot sister than a gentle mother. They should have casted someone like Betty White or Judi Dench to give that lovely persona. Also, the tearing of the dress wasn't as saddening as the original. The stepmother tore the sleeve and the front part, which was pretty sad, but not as sad as the original when the sisters tore it up so much, and when the mother just smiled and left her there without so much as a forbidding Cinderella from going to the ball.Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
...

You know, for everyone in the dark side of the comments who is complaining about how diversity is ruining society and how Cinderella is a "European fairy-tale" I would just like to point out two things.

1.) The very first original Cinderella was an Egyptian fairy tale. It was about a Greek slave girl named Rhodopis who eventually married the King of Egypt. So no, it actually is not a "European fairy-tale."

2.) So...it's perfectly okay for the mice turn into horses, the pumpkins to turn into carriages, for dresses to materialize via magic, and for fairy godmothers to exist, but God forbid they portray another human being with a darker skin color in a freakin make believe story!!! O.O HOLY CRAP IT'S A SIGN OF THE APOCALYPSE!!! DDDDDDDDDDD:Â 

On one side, it's hilarious. On the other, it's really sad. smdh.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
It has been revealed that some pivotal scenes were removed during post-production which made the film feel "rushed" most "especially in the beginning" Other deleted scenes and dialogue which were edited for the Theatrical Cut include the following:

-Little Ella running through the meadow.

-Ella and her mother saving the bird.

-The line "Where there is kindness, there is goodness, and where there is goodness, there is magic." was cut.

-The line "...so I'll know as faraway as I may be, that you will be safe." was cut.

-The dialogue between the guests at Lady Tremaine's party - one of them making a sexist remark - was cut.

-The servants reacting to the Lady Tremaines' demands.

-The servants being dismissed was there, but the dialogue was removed.

-The brief conversation between Lady Tremaine and Ella: "What on earth have you been doing?" she asks her stepdaughter rather cruelly. Ella's soft-spoke response: "Dreaming." It's after this sweet quiet moment when Lady Tremaine grows louder with her response: "Then wake up!"

-Some of the dialogue in the fencing scene was cut.

-The dialogue during the Royal Ball announcement was shortened.

-The dialogue explaining that the glass slippers would be a memento was cut.

-The Grand Duke and Royal Guard questioning Ella after the spell was broken.

-There is a scene after the wedding, but the movie ended with the wedding.

I hope Disney will release an extended cut, or will include the deleted scenes on the home media release.

So for those of you in homogenous Eurotrash countries, get over it. The story represents its people, the American people.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Guys, you need to understand that America is represented as a country that fights against racism and doesn't stand for it *but* when you watch all of our media, 90% of the actors and leading roles are done by Caucasian people and it seems the only 10% are taken by light skinned, as Caucasian looking actors as possible. Â Have you ever heard the quote, "You are what you do, not what you say"? People need to understand that this offends many people such as Native's, Asian, Mixed, Hispanics, Africans, etc. and for a princess film to be have everything changed in it except for the race of their characters hurts many people. Please stop and think before you judge because it's simply the truth that no one wants to admit and I think that is the entire issue we are in this mess in the first place. And what hurts many people the most is that, the people who are being racist are either overreacting, hating someones culture not their color, or *just being mean because they know they are across a screen*. I think the world needs more education on anti-racism. We complain about how bad the world is, here is the number one reason, many of us are refusing to except that this world belongs to *ALL* of us, not just one single group.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
You know what I am tired of this anti-black propaganda of recent years.

I am surrounded by black people (and I'm black myself) and I asked them what they think of this trailer and not a single one. Not. A. Single. One. complained about it being "too white."Â  I also checked several forums and the ones that mentioned this movie had no discussion about it being "too white" either.

You know why??Â  Because we have a Cinderella cartoon already that is all white so this is no surprise and this is not the first all-white Disney film.Â  Enchanted anyone?

All the people grumbling about "blacks want to be in everything" are taking the comments of a few people and using them as a platform to spew their own personal prejudices.Â  If there are blacks complaining about this movie they are in the minority, and not even a vocal minority at that as I have yet to see their comments.

My first and only thought after watching the trailer was that Disney is starting to run out of ideas, we really don't need a remake of their older classics in my opinion.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Lots of racist comments here. Cinderella, along with many fairytales, is much older than they are given credit for (Disney followed TGB's version). The Grimm Brothers were scholars who traveled around collecting stories they weren't "original" by any means, by which we may consider "original." With versions dating as early to Ancient Egypt and China, Cinderella has crossed boundaries, and with Roger and Hammerstein's Cinderella premiering on Disney back in the day with a black Cinderella (Brandy) and her Filipino prince, Disney could've easily added a diverse, interracial MAIN cast-not just a black princess. The prince's Â parents in the above were black and white, yes. The Disney Fandom's racial entitlement is showing again.

That being said it doesn't look like a bad movie. Not really good, but not bad either. I'd watch it.Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: I honestly hate how people are complaining about this movie. Don't like it? Don't watch it. I think Cinderella is a classic, timeless story and why should modernized views change that? Yes, it doesn't have a diverse cast - but other movies do. Look at Big Hero 6 for example. Plenty of viewers complained about the lack of diversity so they changed an originally all Asian cast to white, black, etc. yet the movie was criticized for cheap attempts at making the movie diverse. And yes most Cinderella adaptations always have the same endings yet, how would you feel if they suddenly decided to change the amazing plot line you grew up with? I'm glad they're making a live action version, yes I know what's going to happen but I feel like live action just brings it so much more to life. It feels almost magical just watching the trailer - why should you let the lack of cultural representation and 'overdone' plot stop you from enjoying it?

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
The Cinderella motif may well have originated in classical antiquity. The Greek geographer Strabo recorded in the 1st century BC in his Geographica (book 17, 33) the tale of the Greek slave girl Rhodopis, "Rosey-Eyes", who lived in the colony of Naucratis in Ancient Egypt. It is often considered the oldest known version of the story:

They tell the fabulous story that, when she was bathing, an eagle snatched one of her sandals from her maid and carried it to Memphis; and while the king was administering justice in the open air, the eagle, when it arrived above his head, flung the sandal into his lap; and the king, stirred both by the beautiful shape of the sandal and by the strangeness of the occurrence, sent men in all directions into the country in quest of the woman who wore the sandal; and when she was found in the city of Naucratis, she was brought up to Memphis, became the wife of the king ...

So really you can't open your mouth about who created what first. All this movie is doing is trying to end Racism but no people just have to start the racist call. Everyone is going to watch this movie whether they're European or not. I don't think people would be standing outside the cinema doors telling other people if they're not European then they cannot go see the movie. So just be kind and shut up. There's already enough racism in the world. We don't need to ruin an amazing fairytale because of something stupid.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I must say when Maleficent was first announced and I saw that Jolie was going to be playing her I thought it was a bizarre choice. I thought Helena Bonham Carter would've made a much better Maleficent, and to see her as the Fairy Godmother, to me, is also a bizarre choice of actress. When I think of a loving motherly figure I think more along the lines of Julie Andrews from Princess Diaries or Julie Walters from Harry Potter.

Having said all that about Carter, I do have to admit that this movie looks pretty impressive. They clearly gave the story and made it much more mature with Cinderella having met the Prince prior to the ball. Something that I don't recall being done since the Rodgers and Hammerstien musical with Brandy and Whitney Houston.Â 

I even saw another trailer of this film where (I think it was) the Prince's father basically called bullshit on the Prince's plan to find the woman he fell in love with by fitting the shoe. which was another clever touch to the film.

So overall I am impressed by this trailer but after a being disappointed by Maleficent, I'm going to try not to get my hopes up too high about this film.

Maleficent were Sleeping Beauty- from Grimm's Fairy tales' Briar Rose. And there were actually 12 faeries, one of them was 'Maleficent'. The princess' name wasn't Aurora, but Briar Rose instead. 

Cinderella- came from Grimm's Fairy Tales too, though it has different versions from different European countries. The 'Cinderella" name has many translations too and Grimm's version was quite dark and exaggerated where birds pecked the eyes(of course there's blood) of Cinderella's stepsisters during her wedding and they both died.

Beauty and The Beast I think is the BEST. Both in literature and in movies. I like how "true love conquers everything" concept brought to life in a very romantic way, perhaps it is TRUE LOVE, after all... Imagine a pretty young lady falling in love with a cruel beast?

It was a story about not judging others based on what you see-  Belle looked at the cruel beast's kind side instead of looking at his grotesque physical features and ugliness. 

It was a story about bravery- how Belle or Beauty sacrificed herself to the beast, in replacement for her father's imprisonment and even death. Belle wasn't afraid of the beast too.

It was a story about hope- the beast fell into despair but didn't give up his hope from finding someone to love despite his ugly physical appearance, thanks to his castle attendees and butlers.

It was a story about learning your own lesson- the beast was once a handsome prince, but fell into a spell after the enchantress cursed him for being such a rude, disrespectful, cruel, judgemental, unkind and selfish person. But he changed himself for the sake of good. And he learned all the good traits that he lack from Belle. 

And, it was a story about Love- Beast almost gave up his life to save Belle from the wolves(in the movie), he also set Belle free from imprisonment because he knows where Belle can find true happiness even though he loves her and knows that she was the key to break the spell. Belle, loved him back despite his ugliness, because she found love in his heart. They had romantic feelings for each other after all.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Crazy Cinder-relly....
What amazes me that even in this world of fast, instant information, Â people feel the rushed need to express they're ugly, vile, beyond racist, and completely ignorant opinions without even looking up or researching other Cinderella movie/stage versions with the click of a button. Â  This tells me most of you writing negative comments, and even getting so politically upset over that old racial diversity issue...must be under the age of 18. Or just bored and looking to write cuss words on the internet . Â Because if you would take a minute to educate yourself, Â type in "Whitney Houston & Brandy Â Rodgers & Hammerstein's Cinderella (1997). Â Do the Math Kids! Â This made for TV version is a Broadway style musical (Purchased and presented by, yes, the so-called-raciest Walt Disney Productions)..18 years ago in an attempted to make the most culturally neutral, and racially mixed cast in the history of this genre. Â This fantastic production was probably before some of you bubble heads were born! LOL! Â Take a look people...it has been done. (at that time) Â In a Â grand and lavish way. Â I actually was amused and love the music sung by Brandy and Whitney Houston. And the Country (USA), overall seemed to think this ways so innovative to have thought to have all the characters of different races playing the parts. Â However..looking at it now, Â this little novelty gets distracting when you see Whoopi Goldberg as the queen with her not so black son, and very white guy husband the King.

Bottom line is, This upcoming reboot looks artistically beautiful. Â I love it when Disney spends the money to get every detail more magical than the last. Â Disney at its best, Â takes visual art to a classic level of excellence. Â  As an African American man I will be happy to take my little girls to see this Euro version. So lighten up everybody..it's just a Fairy Tale..if you do not like this new anglo version..don't go. Â Cinderella is the SUPERMAN of all Euro fairy-tails. I'M NOT MAD AT DISNEY AT ALL! There are countless versions of her story reflected in many different cultures around the world. Â All We need to do is stop trying to "fix Everything" while forgetting to have fun, relax and enjoy what looks like a beautiful film. Â 

I'm so sick of political correctness when it comes to Artistic expression and I welcome this All-White, Euro Cast. LOL! Â And I Â encourage Â all of you YouTube Â haters, please shut up..or put up.! Â Or better yet..make your own damn movie/animated version of Cinderella based on your own culture and artistic choices.Â 

Oh yeah, and those of you who thinks its stupid or impossible to have a Black Cinderella...in "our racially divided and hateful America".... type in (Keke Palmer stars as the first African American actress to play the role of Cinderella on Broadway, 2014 "In My Own Little Corner." Rodgers + Hammerstein's CINDERELLA) .....with a White Guy as her Prince! Â OMG!


Anyway I made my point. Â But isn't silly, the present generation thinks everything started when they came into the world. Â Please people, Â before you start venting your negative, and foul mouth trash, know something about what the hell you're talking about. Â 


Use this gift of the internet to open up your brain, instead of your ass.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
As a lifelong Disney fan ever since I was a little kid, all I can say after seeing this first real trailer of Disney's newest live-action remake of another of their animated classics is simply wow :)

The Jungle Book, Alice in Wonderland & Maleficent were all fantastic live-action remakes of Disney animated masterpieces but Cinderella definitely looks to be totally way more faithful to the spirit, essence & the original story of its beloved animated predecessor than the former 3. It really appears as if the phenomenally-gifted Kenneth Branagh has found the always-rare to find perfect balance of staying true to the original while adding new fresh bits & pieces here & there to make this familiar tale feel brand new. Plus the cast he's assembled is just hands down 100% top notch: Downton Abbey co-stars Lily James (Lady Rose) & Sophie McShera (Daisy) as Cinderella & Drizella respectively, Game of Thrones' Richard Madden (The late great Robb Stark) as Prince Charming, Cate Blanchett as The Wicked Stepmother, Helena Bonham Carter as The Fairy Godmother, Sir Derek Jacobi (Gladiator) as The King, Stellan Skarsgard (Thor 1 & 2) as The Grand Duke, Hayley Atwell (The First Avenger: Captain America) as Cinderella's mother & Holiday Grainger (Great Expectations) as Anastasia and as always Kenneth is once again bringing along his go-to composer, the equally-phenomenal Patrick Doyle to score the film. I mean wow :)

The only 2 things that slightly bother me a bit is (1). Hayley as a blonde. Hayley as a blonde is nowhere near as beautiful & attractive as she truly is with her natural brunette hair. They shouldn't have had her dye her beautiful brown hair cause she's way more dreamy as a brunette than as a blonde!!! & (2). I was really hoping that just like in the 2 direct to DVD sequels to the original animated classic that Holiday's Anastasia would be portrayed as a more sympathetic stepsister to Cinderella compared to full-out nasty Drizella & their vicious mother. Anastasia's character evolution from wicked stepsister to misunderstood & surprisingly likable new version of herself as seen in the aforementioned D2DVD sequels was the only thing I loved about those 2 movies!!! Just like in the wonderful Ever After: A Cinderella Story, it was totally refreshing to see at least 1 of Cinderella's stepsisters geniunely care about her like a true sister should so it's a shame that Branagh has seemingly opted to portray Anastasia in her old original full-wicked self. Ah well :(

Aside from those 2 minor hiccups, I simply cannot wait to finally see this next year!!! This is gonna hopefully be an instant Disney classic in every way just like the timeless original :)

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
The people who complain that this is an all white cast unknowingly generate racism because their complaints beg the point - what is stopping black people from creating their own stories and characters? Nobody is stopping them. At the end of the day black people are a minority in the US, it only stands to reason that they wouldn't make up an equal proportion of the cast. While the film is a fantasy, it is loosely set in an age and place which was almost solely compromised of white people. The fact it's a fantasy means they don't need to be strict with that representation, but does it actually matter? Seems like an asinine thing to have a teary about. Would you have preferred the director to have been forced to cast a black cinderella, even if it was against his vision as an artist?

Don't take me the wrong way. I would be happy if it was an all black cast and would have about the same level of interest in the film (see: none. I'm male.), I just don't see why racial representation matters. I don't think black people are demeaned simply because they aren't included, nor do I believe they would suddenly be empowered for being represented.

If you worry about the skin colours of characters in a fantasy film, I'd suggest you have it pretty easy in life. People with genuine struggles don't fret over such things.

TL; DR
Greurgh.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
OKAY, WE GET IT, THE ORIGINAL FAIRYTALE WAS SET IN FRANCE IN MEDIEVAL TIMES, BUT HAVE YOU CONSIDERED THAT, AS A FREAKIN MAGICAL BEING, THE FAIRY GODMOTHER COULD VERY WELL BE OF COLOR? And don't get me wrong, I'm a huge fan of HBC, but I'm only saying that there is always room for representation, if you really care to have it, without it being a fucking maid standing in a corner.

PS: In this trailer, the evil stepmother and her two daughters show up wearing really heavy make up, something that was totally not a thing in the late 18th century, women, especially upper class ladies, would never be caught dead with a full face of make up on. It was only wore by actresses and whores. And that is just a single bit of all the historical inaccuracy featured in this film (don't even get me started on the hairstyles) but oHH NO GOD FORBID PEOPLE OF COLOR IN A 2015 MOVIE ADAPTION OF AN EUROPEAN TALE!!! So yeah, don't pull the "I'm not racist okay I just really care about historical accuracy" card when you're clearly being racist.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
It's a fairy tale in a fairy tale world, you could just randomize ethnies for the sake of diversity and it wouldn't be wrong... but...
In the other hand, I find it pretty ridiculous and even offensive to try to force in a movie all races of the world just to make people feel "represented". It would be dumb to have a movie about the US civil war with a bunch of ethnically diverse patriots fighting for the freedom of the ethnically diverse slaves.
As it would be ridiculous to have a movie about ancient india with white and black people as the lead characters.

As it is ridiculous to expect ethnically diverse people in a movie set up in the rennaisance, like Cinderella is! There weren't a majority of Indians nor east Asians (and for sure not latin Americans) in Europe back then, and they would definitely not be the aristocracy or royality. It would be even worse if they portrayed the few black people there as servants, or your random Jewish dude being addicted to wealth.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I'm not excited about seeing this, but it's not for the reasons most people are complaining of. Â I see there are plenty of comments already concerning topics like racism and feminism. Â Of course there's no people of color in this, it's a Grimm fairy tale, set in Europe. Â It only makes sense. Â Anyway, we already had the Brandy version of this, and it was good too. Â If it's such a problem for you, re-watch that one instead of going to the theatrical release. Â 

I see where people come from complaining about how Cinderella simply wished and didn't do anything to actively rescue herself except be pretty enough to catch the eye of someone who could do something (a common theme in Grimm fairy tales), but it was fabricated during a time where much wasn't expected of women, and wasn't necessarily the Grimm Brothers' doing at that. Â Remember, their job was to go around and listen to fables given via word of mouth and document it. Â While they may have edited them some based on their own views, most probably stayed the same as they were told previously. Â It's why I like stories like Bluebeard and The Little Mermaid. Â Sure, in the original the mermaid dies at the end, but she did her best and sacrificed herself for her love (one-sided as it was), and Bluebeard's wife didn't just accept her fate and fought back when she was to be murdered, ending up victorious, so one can't say all Grimm stories are the same. Â I suppose those versions wouldn't really suit Disney's target audience, though. Â I enjoyed Cinderella 3: A Twist in Time (once that terribly tacky opening sequence was over) because Cinderella had to actively do things to regain her happy ending, and she looked amazing doing it. Â Sorry, I have this issue where I go off on tangents. Â Anyway.

My problem with this new film is that, at least in the trailer, save for the preemptive meeting with the prince on horseback and the flashback scenes with the mother, all of the scenes are from Disney's cartoon. Â It's just a live action version of something they've already done over half a century ago. Â I suppose the story of Cinderella has been twisted just as often as Snow White, and the fairy tale universe itself (i.e., Once Upon A Time, Fables/The Wolf Among Us, The 10th Kingdom, Into the Woods, etc.), but do we ever really get tired of it? Â I hope this version will have some sort of little twist at the end. Â Just her managing to get out of the locked room by herself would be enough for me, instead of having to rely on friendly rodents. Â Really, who would pay to go to a theater, only to watch something they've seen before? Â Well, it's Cinderella, so a lot of people will, but I think I'll just stay home that day and watch the original instead while waiting for this to hit Redbox or NetFlix, at least until I hear something about this version that makes me believe it's worth the expense.

Interestingly, the Broadway production borrowed from the Disney version as well - at least in the costume department, with dresses looking like Cinderella's (worn by a background dancer at the ball) and Belle's (worn by Ella).

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Does anyone besides me actually remember that Disney had in fact produced a Cinderella film with a black woman as it's lead?

It came out in 1997 and it starredÂ Brandy Norwood as Cinderella, Filipino-American actor Paolo Montalban as the Prince and even had Whoopi Goldberg in it. For me it was the only live-action Cinderella out there growing up.

I think it makes some sense that if Disney is doing a live-action reboot of Cinderella as a feature film, they're going to base the ethnic palate be a bit closer to the animated version of Cinderella from the 1950's or on the original French story.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
There's nothing new here, so I'm not paying to see it. But it looks amazing!

On the subject of racial representation, I think anyone who sees diversity as a negative is racist, but I respect and uphold every artist's right to tell the story they want to tell. Historically, Europe was predominantly white but not entirely so - diversity was definitely a thing (ever heard of the Moors? The Romani?). Given the expense of traveling, I have to conclude that the only non-white people who would've frequented Europe would have been wealthy if not royal or noble personages. Also, I wonder how many people in this comment section would pay to see a movie based on an African or Asian fairy tale.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
About the "boobs spilling out" I don't think it's inappropriate at all. You know, most kids are actually exposed to NAKED breasts from when they're just born, (the actual function of having a pair of tits is so that you can feed babies) so well... in my opinion the boobs do no harm.

And also, I am not sure about this, but I think that at the time and place that this story seems to have taken place, most women wore corsets that pushed the boobs even higher up then in this movie. But you know, I could be mistaking it for some other time.

Anyway, her dress does not seem to be following any strict code for a certain fashion era, but I belive it's completely suitable for our time because at least here in Sweden most of us seem comfortable with women showing a little bit of their chest. Especially in dressed up occasions.

Comment: There has already been an adaptation of Cinderella with a more "diverse" cast. R&B singer Brandy starred as Cinderella, while the late and great Whitney Houston starred as the Fairy Godmother. The cast also featured an Asian prince (son of an African-American queen and Caucasian king), a Caucasian step-mother, one Caucasian step-sister, and one African-American step-sister. If you want diversity, watch that and stop bitching about this movie featuring a mostly Caucasian cast. Sure, it's probably not as visually engaging as this feature film, but it's still worth the watch, especially if you want more ethnic flavor.Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Hm...Live action Sleeping Beauty(Granted different ending), Live action Snow White(is this one by disney?), Live action Beauty and the Beast(Definitely not disney...I don't think), Live action Alice in Wonderland(this wasn't disney either was it?), Live action Cinderella.

So...we have Aladdin, Little Mermaid, Pocahontas, Mulan, Lion King(photorealistic CG obviously), The Hunchback of Notre Dame, The Rescuers, Lilo & Stitch(You think they wouldn't?), The Black Cauldron and Hercules for the remainder of the recognized Animated Disney Movies that are likely to get a Live action counterpart.Â  Did I forget Tarzan?Â  Probably forgot Tarzan...

My bet is that Mulan will be next, simply because it's more action oriented than any of the others and female lead with love as a sub-plot.Â  My list goes like this of ones to release in order.

Mulan
The Hunchback of Notre Dame
Pocahontas
Little Mermaid
Lilo & Stitch
The Black Cauldron
Aladdin
Hercules
The Rescuers
Lion King(least likely to also get made at all)

Also for people complaining(I dunno I've only read comments about OTHER people complaining.) there's a bunch of movies left to do, just wait for those.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: There does not need to be black versions of every movie and fairy tale! I don't need a black superman, I don't need a Spanish Snow white either! What would be nice is races with their own fairy tale. Also, don't try to make it different just because the person is Indian or something. Make a unique story and use different races. There's no need to take the same story and make twists and turns so it sounds more like what a black person would go through. If you want to make a story that takes place in another country, then do it!show off that country and make us interested in the culture! Don't try to conform to "making everybody happy" No body wants to go home with a group of friends and ask Â "do you want to watch the African, Scottish or Asian Cinderella?" All cultures want to have their own fairy tales and heroes in their own right in relation to their culture. Just like Japan has samurai and Europeans have knights. I understand wanting to see people in movies that relate to your culture more but would you rather have a fairy tale that has been colored to look like you or something original that has meaning to where you came from? So please, if you want to see this movie, then see it. If not, then don't. It's your choice of how you want to waste your time. Now, I'm done wasting my time by making this rant Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Okay I have heard enough of the "why are there mostly white people in this".Â 
Guess what? It is because the film is based of a story, written and set by Europeans, at a time in Europe where it was mostly white people.Â Please read through my comment and you might understand why that is actually a very valid argument and why it actually promotes diversity.
First of all, I am not even white, but I have to point out that trying to force PoC in this is a form of cultural appropriation. Believe me, I hate white supremacists more than any group of people, and due to bad experiences, I have a certain disliking to white people in general, but to me, blacks or asians trying to get in on Classical European literature works, is a form of them submitting to white supremacy, that white culture is superior then there own culture. I stand for diversity, and a form of multiculturalism very few understand. To me, I would rather see 5 disney movies, with each movie being an adaptation of a literary classical or folklore story that belongs to a certain culture, with all the characters being cast of that ethnicity, not see 5 movies with all races mixed together. I would rather see an Arabian Nights adaptation, with an all-Arab or Persian cast, and a Chinese folklore adaptation with an all Chinese cast, and an Indian legend adaptation with an all Indian/Pakistani cast, and a African folklore adaptation with an all Black cast, and a Western-European classic adaptation with an all white cast. When keeping all these different stories to their own ethnic casts, you are actually preserving each and every culture's heritage. When you mix the cast for adaptations of each of these stories, you are destroying them. I would be equally pissed to see a white guy in Mulan or Aladdin, as I would be to see a black person in Cinderella.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Wow, for all its flaws, I was still kinda hoping this would turn out to be more like Maleficent. Maleficent wasn't particularly well made, but it had elements to draw you in; it had Angelina Jolie looking exactly like the classic villain, it had a gritty origin story that completely re-wrote the tale and gave new dimension to the character, and it had a great twist ending that made it all worth it despite the flaws. I want to hold out hope that MAYBE the "kindness" thing they keep repeating is going to have a similar angle, like maybe the stepmother and stepsisters are secretly jealous of Cindy because they thought her dad loved her and her mom more but Cindy's unwavering kindness will turn them around at the end and they'll be like a real family or something, but that's definitely not the vibe I'm getting from the trailer. I'm also not a fan of the costuming, Cindy's dress looks nothing like the original and it doesn't look period appropriate either and Lady Tremaine also doesn't appear to look or act anything like the classic villain, and between her and the fairy godmother looking way too fabulous and not at all like the original middle-aged matriarchs it feels like the movie is going to be all style and no substance. All in all, it looks like it's going to be JUST the same story but with some extra scenes of Cindy and her parents and the prince and nothing new or exciting or nostalgic to actually draw in a crowd like Maleficent.

Am I the only one scared by the way this Prince "Charming" behaves? It reminds me too much of Christian Grey in the 50 Shades of Grey trailer, the tone is too measured and slow. Many people are complaining about how women are stereotyped into being weak and helpless (which they too often are) but have you considered the equal and opposite stereotyping of men? The menÂ designed to cater to female fancy must be brave, strong, reliable, forward to the point where it would be uncomfortable if they weren't found attractive - this is exactly what the male lead reflects. And I get the feeling it's becoming worse - though I haven't seen the original in ages, I remember the original Prince Charming was less determinedly masculine (IN A GOOD WAY - there is nothing more beautiful than a good romantic duet :) ).

- a girl sick of sterotypes generally

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: WOW! So many people hating. I get that the trend of dark remakes has been going on for long, but this is fine. Not every film needs a princess going through what seems to be an acid trip if it was written by Alice Cooper, not every film needs villains to be needlessly turned into tragic heroes, not every remake needs to have violence, dark themes, total changes or have PG-13 rating. This looks all right, and it looks like it keeps the spirit of Cinderella but also gives it some new stuff. Once it's out, go watch it and then hate it on it or whatever. I don't like sappy romances, but I love Disney films. This reminds me of Cinderella more than crap like Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland did the original.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: I don't see why people are making a fuss about a casting choice! Are all the cast white? Yes. Does it automatically make it racist? No. I realise that it may come across as that but I highly doubt that's the case. I've seen the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical version of Cinderella with a Black Cinderella, a white step family, the prince is Asian and the queen is black and king is white yet it today still remains one of my FAVOURITE films. The race does not make a film. The acting does. You could have a mixed race cast but if the acting isn't good it's not going to be a good film. The same goes for an all white cast, if the acting is rubbish then likely the films not going to be much better. Â For all we know the actors or actresses could be mixed race but still look white. I realise that racism is a major issue and I think it's awful but not everything is an attack on race.I get peoples point about this being story of Northern European origins and at the time that it was written, the idea of a black or any other race person being wealthy or being of high standing was not realistic and I still find it appalling how anyone of a different race was treated but it was reality though it does not make it right. Does this mean that a new take can't be done? No. This is a traditional take on the story and casting and so I think people need to understand that.Â If there was racism going on behind the casting choice (not casting another race because of personal prejudice) then that's a real shame. I think this film looks good and I'll be interested in seeing how well it does.

Comment:
Letâ€™s try to be totally fair here.Â  I have been reading lots of notes from people who think the trailer gives away the whole movie.Â  But you only think that because you know the story.Â  Itâ€™s difficult, but imagine you didnâ€™t know it. Â 

Whatâ€™s the significance of the mice turning into horses?
Whatâ€™s the significance of the fairy?
Whatâ€™s the significance of the glass shoes?Â  Is it bad that some lady got hold of one of them?Â 
Whatâ€™s the significance of that party the girl is attending?Â  ( By the way, who is that girl? )
Who is the guy she is dancing with?Â  Is he a gardener?Â  a soldier? a cook? a garbage man?Â  Why is he relevant?
Why is she spending all her time with that guy?Â  It's a party.Â  Why doesn't she spread herself around more?Â  Â 

So you see?Â  If you donâ€™t know the story, the trailer actually doesnâ€™t tell us much.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Oh for goodness sakes, it is a FAIRY-TALE, it is MAKE BELIEVE! And yes, back then, in those times of which they are set and the first published story of Cinderella was in 1634 where woman depending on men was something that ACTUALLY happened and even then if you go back further the story seemed to originate in Ancient Greek times which, once again, woman stayed at home, dependent on what the husband can earn and she cooked and cleaned. So yes, woman are dependent on men in these stories and now times have changed but given Anderson and Grimm (most well known) wrote these stories in the 17 or 1800's or whatever it is woman were STILL dependent on men then as well so the men wrote from what they knew and in those times woman didn't have jobs, went out, had meals at fancy restaurants by themselves etc because it would of been wrong for a woman to exercise her independence.

So yes we have moves based on the ORIGINAL works because if you have seen the modern fairy tales that have been made they are all crap, as long as you teach the little girls that they can be independent on their own then let them have the fantasy of finding a prince and living a non stressful life because as soon as they grow up they realize they won't be having that and they need to make it on their own. IÂ grew up with these stories and as a 31 year old woman I didn't throw a tantrum because I didn't get my prince and castle, these stories never scarred me so let the little girls have their fantasies, it is HEALTHY for them to pretend they may get a prince, it is called having an imagination and besides, one or two MIGHT get a prince, look at Kate, I doubt she grew up thinking 'oh one day I am going to marry William!' when she was 12+ (age to more or less start to let go of these fantasies and realizing that, ya know, princes are not for everyone) for her, she was just lucky that she actually WAS able to nab herself a prince.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Why is there all of this racist nonsense flying around in the comments? This story is set in a time and place were multiculturalism wasn't much of a thing, which sucked and everything, but my lord can we just accept that there is actual historical reasoning behind why they cast white people into the main roles? It's not racism, it's realistic, which Â maybe isn't the entire point of Cinderella, but it's the way the story was originally meant to be portrayed. It says nothing of a "white washed" America or whatever the heck else people want to call it. What if someone decided to tell the story of Mulan and replaced the characters with white people? It wouldn't make sense, and it would be stupid to try and shove a culture into another one where they weren't present. Maybe if they had retold Cinderella in a setting that would make sense with another culture it would be cool, or something like that, but hating on Disney for sticking to the original story is just a waste of energy and, frankly, kind of ignorant. If you want to "fight the power of racism" and all that jazz, please get out of the comment section on Youtube and actually do something in the physical world to promote change.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
The all-white cast of the Good Earth (a novel *about Chinese culture which took place in China and is staunchly culturally Chinese*, dealing with a part of Chinese history) or 21? Jake Gyllenhaal the Prince of *PERSIA*? John Wayne as Genghis Khan? Jennifer Connelly playing a woman who was Hispanic in real life? Mena Suvari or Angelina Jolie playing black women? The Last Airbender?? The King and I? Tonto? Rooney Mara as Tiger Lily??? The list is long. Add cultural appropriation to the rest and the list gets far longer. 'FOH with that hypocrisy. Races are swapped out all the time for white actors to play them. 30 Days of Night, Argo, etc. etc. etc.
You people complaining are scared as hell that you won't have it made anymore. You don't care about having the luxury of always being first choice; you just care if that luxury is somehow lessened and fear if it'll taken from you. How pathetic.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: My comment may or may not make sense to some but I feel like this ''re-imagining is gonna confuse a lot of people, this is not a direct female of the animated Walt Disney version of Cinderella, and I think Disney is making a mistake by naming it Cinderella its going to add confusion . For starters this is not a musical everyone like the animated version so you won't be hearing A Dream Is A Wish Your Heart Makes , Bibbidi Bobidi Boo etc. Jaq and Gus won't be in this or wear clothes like in the original , so ever since I heard that Disney was doing this I was dissapointed because people are going to confuse it with the animated one. Also notice that they are all British in the Walt Disney animated one they all had American accents , also the stepmother here has red hair in the animated one she had grey hair , yes her name is Lady Treamine like in the cartoon, yes Anastasia and Drizella are the names of the stepsisters etc. yes Cinderella is blonde and has a blue dress , but don't let Disney fool you all guys this is not a direct REMAKE OF THE CARTOON ONE WE ALL KNOW ITS NOT A MUSICAL ETC. Stupid director Kenneth Branagh wanting to name it this Cinderella , they should have called it Ella to not get people confused !!!! with the original cartoon one.Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: There have been several comments that this film is incorrect to cast people of colour in any role. Firstly, it is a fantasy movie with mice turning into horses and a pumpkin into a carriage. If you can suspend belief over those points, the ethnic make-up of the cast shouldn't trouble you at all. Secondly, there were people of non-European, non-white descent in Europe in the early modern period (and in other periods too). This was particularly the case at court where having a black or brown servant was desirable. For example, the 19th-century Russian poet Pushkin was part African, as his grandfather (or great-grandfather... I can't remember which) had been a slave brought to Russia by a wealthy merchant in the early 18th century.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I enjoy Disney movies (I have grown up on them), but can we see an Asian Cinderella, or an African Cinderella, or even an Arab Cinderella. What a bout a modern Cinderella?Â 

More diversity, in the movies you make Disney. I get it it's a classic, but classics have been re imagined all the time. I truly believe that the animated magic that spawned the lion king, lilo and stitch and snow white, can create a more diverse body of work, than just showing Cinderella over and over again. Just look into the myths and legends all over the world, there are so many inspirations/stories to tell, than just the Euro-centric image you have portrayed.

Why not a myth involving a Baba Yaga, or Anansi the spider? Just to name a few.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I have skipped the new Snow White, Snow White and the Huntsman, and several other fairytale "re imaginings." I especially hated the very concept of Maleficent. These fairy tales were created to teach children lessons. They were stories about right and wrong. Now these movies either skip the lesson entirely, or turn it on its head. So often they teach bad lessons or attempt to my the villain a hero. It makes me sick, and that is coming from someone who read the original, gruesome versions of the stories.
This, though; I think I might see this.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
In my opinion it looks the same as everything done before. The trailer is edited to make it seem epic with loud music, but it looks quite normal. This story is overused and getting tired. If you are going to do something again do it right. You don't have to make it action packed or change the story likeÂ Snow White and the Huntsman or Mirror Mirror. But like those movies you should take something over done and make it more interesting in costume, casting, and location, etc. My favrouite retelling of this story isÂ Ever After: A Cinderella Story. it's simple but really alluring.

About the race dispute in the comment section,
You're looking for "Cinderella" staring Brandy. It's also disney and has almost every race. In fact it's here on Youtube if you search it. Just watch that. It's a bit more musical but it's not that different than something like this. I like that one a lot.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Now that they have made Cinderella for the Nth time, I would love to see a direct adaptation of the original Chinese tale that made all of this possible: Ye Xian, a.k.a. Yeh-Shen.

Like Cinderella both embody the struggle against oppression by society and rotten culture. The story of Ye Xian is more honest and beautiful than Cinderella, in my opinion. Plus, the role of fairy godmother is fulfilled by a talking fish (sent by the girl's mother from the afterlife)! :DÂ 

If fairies are mandatory for Ye Xian to be made, they could very easily add carbuncles (rock-fairies) to the plot (they fit the setting of cave-dwellers). Although the guardian spirit (the talking fish) makes it more unique.ï»¿

Maybe if they changed the whole dynamic and made it a dystopian society then maybe it would work. But until that happens, let the european stories remain how they were written. Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
This actually looks pretty good! It's surprisingly close to the original Cinderella (well, the cartoon one, at least), and the cast is new and refreshing as they are not all uber famous actors. Some people are complaining about the lack of racial diversity, but I am a woman of color myself, and I find no problem with it in this movie at least. It's historically accurate (I'm actually glad there aren't tons of black people in this movie. As accurate as Disney likes to be, they all would have had to be depicted as slaves or servants, and as horrible as that is, it's what people of color would have been in that era. I think we can all agree that has no place in this movie. Besides, it's a fairytale. Your kid doesn't give a shit what color skin the princess has, as long as she-or he- gets to wear a tiara just like hers). Just as movies like Mulan, Princess and the Frog, Aladdin, and Frozen were, the peoples' races are just as they would have been in that country and time period. That's some ace research and historical representation on Disney's part if I may say so. The only person who could have been more racially diverse is the Fairy Godmother, and that's my only complaint. She should have been something other than white, as she's a fairy, not a born and bred European. That was a wasted chance, imo. Otherwise though, I'm excited to see this! It looks really well-done, and I hope it turns out as awesome as it's presented to be! Though I must agree they showed WAY too much in this trailer... -__-
Â And if you REALLY desire a racially diverse version of Cinderella, go watch Roger and Hammerstein's rendition of Cinderella. It's my favorite, and extremely well done! Cinderella is black, and so is her fairy godmother and the Queen. The Prince is Asian, and even one of the stepsisters is black. I absolutely recommend it, 10/10!

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
When I watched it for the first time it legit gave me goosebumps and I ended up watching it more than 5 times in a row hehehe. The plot being the same as the old and classic Disney version was actually what I liked the most about this new one. Yes, we do want to see those stories that have been part of our childhood, magically created in real life with beautiful characters. Disney classic fairy tails are perfect the way they are and because we are so used to them since we were little kids, we consider them as the main version or the 'true' version (even though they aren't). Therefore, the only way to make it 'better' is by using innovative cinematic techniques, NOT by changing or adding new unrelated elements to the story. I actually find it disappointed when they recreate old movies and introduce a whole lot of things just to make it different or "unseen". It's as if they were trying to change our childhood memories and the only thing that goes through my mind is: "No... that's not right! That's not what happened in the story... They're wrong". It's the same kind of disappointment when we watch a movie based on a book we already read, because the images of our imagination are already in our heads (or in this case, images of our memories) and when people show it in a complete different way is kinda upsetting. Maleficent was different though, because they didn't tell us the same story in a complete different way. They introduced us a background (the truth underlying the classic story) and that's what made it different & good at the same time. Also, another thing that I found remarkably good in Cinderella is the casting chosen, especially Lily James. To play the main character you gotta know how to act as a real-princess (I'm using hyphen here because I'm not saying 'real' as in a "true princess", but as in a princess closer to reality). Well.. to explain it better, we don't live in Monarchies anymore so princesses are not part of our daily lives. Therefore, to represent something unreal (a princess) as real as possible, Lily James used nothing else than emotions - universal feelings !! - something we all can relate to :) She didn't have blank faces or fake crystallized tears like Mia Wasikowska in Alice in Wonderland or Elle Fanning in Maleficent. You can easily see her emotions only through her facial expressions, like her reaction when Lady Tremaine tells her to call her Madam, when she meets the prince (in this particularly scene she reminded me of Kate Winslet playing Rose in Titanic by the way *-*), her look of surprise when she touches the white horse, or even before that, when the fairy godmother appears it's possible to see her red face and swallow eyes because she was crying. PLUS she did all that still having the adorable, sweet, gentle and beautiful looks of a true princess. So in summary, Lily James easily portrayed Cinderella as a princess but simultaneously as a real person. I won't even talk about the prince (Richard Madden) but for now, all I'm gonna say is that when he said: "Believe me they are all looking at you" WOW! My heart melted. hahaha. In conclusion, I absolutely loved the fact that it followed the original one. I even loved how the colors of her dresses are the same from the old version and how she also uses a cloth on her hair as a maid. I loved all the similarities and even the small differences. And I loved how the dearest Disney princess was portrayed by the gorgeous Lily James :) I'm sooooooo looking forward to watching this movie <3Â 

Note: this is MY opinion, based on the trailer only ;) Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: Am I the only one excited about this? It's SO much better than all those horrible remakes where they hand the princes/heroine a sword and have her kill people and are like "there. now she's like a male warrior. NOW we can respect her." I just think Cinderella gets such a bad rap! The concept in valuing truth, patience, kindness and forgiveness above all, even in the face of abuse and bullying is REALLY powerful. It's so much easier to be like "here, kill the bad guy." But let's face it, that never happens in real life. This is a much more challenging, yet rewarding message. And as for the fancy gown at the ball- the point is, since this is the Perrault (not German) version of the fairytale, she gets rewarded with the gown from the fairy godmother and with help from the animals, because she is a good person! She gets rewarded with luxury and extravagance, for once, at the ball, because it is supposed to reflect her internal beauty. The idea is that good people, who are strong enough to remain good people, win out in the end. An optimistic lesson, yes, but probably more applicable to the real world, and a nice change from all the villain-obsessed flicks out lately.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
Good lord, was it really necessary to slather that much makeup onto Richard Madden?

Why does common sense go out the window when a production gets a huge budget? His skin is fine, just clean it and moisturize. If the lenses and lighting are good, he's going to look good. With 35mm and panavision cine glass, you're going to see the makeup and then if you try to blend it in post, you've created a bunch of work that never needed to be done and ended up making a really plastic looking image from $30,000 lenses. Waste of time and money and it doesn't look good. Everyone in the production chain has gotta get paid I guess.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
*sighs heavily after looking at some of the comment threads* why do people have to make such a big deal about whether the cast is diverse or not? It's not going to make much of a difference whether the cast is all Caucasian, African, Latino, Asian, Native American, Hawaiian, Russian, or Indian (you can add more to the list if you'd like); the only thing that's going to be effected is the setting. Disney chose to recreate the European version of Cinderella, so having a 95% Caucasian cast is to be expected. And before anyone says it, I am fully aware that Europe is not all Caucasian, but it is mostly Caucasian. And also, just because the cast is mostly Caucasian, doesn't automatically make the movie bad unless you the viewer decides that it will. 

That being said, while I think the trailer was too revealing, I think the film will be alright over all.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
"Cinderella": In the Brothers Grimm version, one of Cinderella's evil stepsisters cuts off her toes, and the other her heel so they can both fit into the tiny glass slipper. The prince is notified by little doves that there is blood on the shoe, and finally discovers that the true owner is Cinderella. Once the stepsisters realize that they should try to win favor with Cinderella (after all, she will be queen), they attend her wedding, only to have their eyes pecked out by birds

SOME OTHER SIDENOTES ON THIS STORY: Cinderella doesn't have a fairy godmother. Rather, she plants a tree by her mother's grave and prays under it every day. She finds her dresses to wear to each ball under the tree (there are three in the story, not one like in the movie). She is still helped by animals, though specifically birds, not mice. Also, she doesn't just lose her shoe because she is in a rush. The clever prince covers the steps in pitch to make her stick to them, but she only loses a shoe in the process.

(1:30 into the trailer)

ME: Nope, every single live-action version Disney does is going to suck.

This was flat, unenchanting, written-in, paint-by-number, and looked worse than all of the movies like "Ella Enchanted" which basically tried to knock off of animated versions. You hear that, Disney? Your live action movies are worse than the movies that are made to try and imitate you and be pale facsimilies. I couldn't even watch past 1:30 because I realized it just went "downhill" from there. Why don't they just throw in some evil army for Cinderella to defeat in a fantasy battle while they're at it and complete the downgrade... That or Johnny Depp.

I really don't care that they're going to ruin "The Jungle Book" because that was already ruined to begin with, but we need to start a petition to keep them from trashing "Beauty and the Beast" before they begin filming.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment: a lot of people are saying that the girl isn't BEAUTIFUL enough...maybe that is the message they are trying to translate. Although the step mom and the stepsisters are beautiful on the outside their personalities are ugly and rude.Â The girl playing cinderella is by no means plain or ugly she is average but what is shining through is her personality we hear her mom saying that she is very nice and kind meaning that she has a humble and caring personality which is far more beautiful and important Â than that of outer beauty. I personally think this is a positive message for little girls, young girls, and women in general. Beauty fades but your inner most beautiful personality lasts longer. I applaud the director for this take of the a classic fairy tale story.Â

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I think this looks quite good for being a live-action, apparently non-musical telling of the Cinderella tale...although I am a fanatic for the Disney classics and don't imagine that anything could ever possibly be anywhere near as good as them (or the Rodgers & Hammerstein Cinderella, for that matter), I still look forward to it. It's true, though, that the trailer appears to be pretty much the entire film condensed to under 3 minutes. And unless it's deliberately omitting something, it seems to be basically the same fairy tale over again.Â 
HBC as the fairy godmother would've convinced me even if I hadn't already been expecting to like it, though.Â 


What with this, 'Maleficent,' the Sleeping Beauty re-release, that 7D cartoon (which looks rather deeply unappealing to me), and Into the Woods (which involves a version of Cinderella as well as mentions Sleeping Beauty), Disney is really putting a lot of focus on their earliest princesses--or things related to those original fairy tales. I think I would rather see, instead of just further lavish live-action remakes, some real quality continuations of the princess stories...maybe even crossing them over with one another...but that would take a heck of a lot more inspiration.Â

Comment: People might be thinking why isn't Helenea Bonham Carter playing Lady Tremaine. The answer is simple, she wanted to play a very nice character after playing so many evil characters. Besides, she already played a mean woman, who forced a young girl to do tons of housework in 'Les Miserables'. Robbie Coltrane, who played Hagrid in 'Harry Potter', said in an interview that he wanted to play a very friendly guy after playing so many villains and nasty characters.Â

Step 4: Cast Helena Bonham-Carter, Johnny Depp or Helena Bonham-Carter AND Johnny Depp. Or at least Mandy Moore or Kristen Bell or whoever can do some bubblegum pop to print Grammy awards.
Step 5: Make enough money for your great-great-great godchildren to retire.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I'm sorry, but "Have courage and be kind"? That's the best you can come up with, Disney, for meaningful parting words? I know it sounds so picky but just that wooden phrasing is putting me off. It just seems emotionless and careless. I was expecting the script to be a little less painful than that...
And is anyone else bothered by the color of her dress? I prefer the light blue-gray from the original over this almost gaudy bright blue-purple color, which (as someone very accurately said before me) looks like something out of Nanny McPhee
I wish Disney would spend more time and effort on their movies instead of churning out these mediocre, CGI heavy pieces. Cinderella is my favorite Disney Princess, but everything about this trailer seems careless and money-seeking.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I think this movie looks like it will be charming. I don't see it as Disney re-making a film just because they already did the story once. Re-making would imply they're basing it off the original movie. This one looks like it's just them doing the story of Cinderella again, with a much more fleshed out story and less singing. Not a re-make, but a re-telling (though I admit, they do use the same names for the step-family and the general designs to a degree, such as Drizella's weird bow on her head). Either way, though, this is not the first live-action adaptation Disney did of Cinderella since making the animated adaptation.

To my amusement, this movie will be directed by the one and only Gilderoy Lockhart, and will have the great Sir Derek Jacobi in it.

Title: Disney's Cinderella Official US Trailer
Comment:
I wasn't impressed with Maleficent. The Aurora's story from the animated movie didn't stay the same as the animated movie where they crossed. If they had just told the story of Maleficent and left Aurora out of it, the movie would have been much better.

I've noticed errors and it's only the trailer. First, though we don't know for sure if they met before the events of the movie. Cinderella and the Prince didn't meet. But that's me being nit picky. Second. The horse drove the carriage not a duck. I didn't event notice Bruno (the dog) Fourth. The mice don't talk. She may not have spoken to them a lot in the movie but at least she could understand them. And another nit-picky thing. Her dress isn't right.

If this is what Disney is going to do, future generations are going to grow up not knowing good Disney movies. My rant is done, I'm getting off my soap box.

Comment: When i first saw this i was just like omg........... here we go either this is going to start a new live action reboot of all the classic disney movies.........(which i am so skeptical about )............and am not looking forward to...............................................or straight up war will begin !!! I think i could kinda agree with what some people would say about this sucking........ i think its just because i'm coming from the perspective of being raised on these movies like so many others and feeling sentimental with the classic versions because that was what i was introduced to in the first place and going to WDW Orlando Florida so many times growing up being used to the versions of the characters there, i guess i could not imagine them any different.......i get what Disney are trying to do with the new technology is give these next generations the same type of experience that we had, being given these movies as children which i think is great cause its keeping like the legendary stories and morals alive but still it trips the fuck out of me...... and it sucks cause i cant see the same songs being used in this new movie as the original or any of the others if they continue to reboot them which sucks because they are for me what made the movies !!!!!( plus i get really unstable with change of any sort) ino its gunna be something ill have to get used to but yeh!!!
